sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Aspergillosis, Invasive, salvage therapy: 70 mg IV infusion on day 1, followed by 50 mg IV daily thereafter; duration of therapy depends upon severity of patient's underlying disease, recovery from immunosuppression, and clinical response
  • Aspergillosis, Invasive - HIV infection: 70 mg IV on day 1, followed by 50 mg IV daily; treat until the peripheral blood CD4+ count is more than 200 cells/microliter and clinical response is evident
  • Candida endophthalmitis: (alternative therapy) 70 mg IV infusion on day 1, followed by 50 mg IV daily for at least 4 to 6 weeks
  • Candidemia: (primary therapy) 70 mg IV infusion on day 1, then 50 mg IV once daily thereafter; duration of therapy depends upon clinical response and microbiological response; continue for a minimum of 14 days beyond the first negative culture
  • Candidiasis, Cardiovascular system infection: 70 mg IV infusion on day 1, followed by 50 to 150 mg IV daily thereafter
  • Candidiasis, Osteoarticular infection: (alternative therapy) 70 mg IV infusion on day 1, then 50 mg IV daily for at least 2 weeks, followed by fluconazole therapy
  • Candidiasis of the esophagus: (alternative therapy) 70 mg IV infusion on day 1, followed by 50 mg IV daily for 14 to 21 days
  • Candidiasis of the esophagus: 50 mg IV once daily for 7 to 14 days after symptom resolution (manufacturer dosing)
  • Candidiasis of the esophagus - HIV infection: 50 mg IV once daily for 14 to 21 days (guideline dosing) OR 7 to 14 days after symptom resolution (manufacturer dosing)
  • Disseminated candidiasis, Chemotherapy-induced neutropenia; Prophylaxis: (alternative therapy) 70 mg IV infusion on day 1 of induction chemotherapy, followed by 50 mg IV daily thereafter for the duration of neutropenia
  • Disseminated candidiasis, chronic: (alternative therapy) 70 mg IV infusion on day 1, then 50 mg IV daily for 1 to 2 weeks, followed by oral fluconazole therapy when clinically stable
  • Disseminated candidiasis, Intra-abdominal abscesses, peritonitis, or pleural space infections: 70 mg IV infusion on day 1, then 50 mg IV once daily thereafter; duration of therapy depends upon clinical response and microbiological response; continue for a minimum of 14 days beyond last positive culture
  • Febrile neutropenia, Empiric antifungal therapy: 70 mg IV infusion on day 1, then 50 mg IV once daily thereafter; duration of therapy depends upon clinical response with empirical therapy continued until resolution of neutropenia; patients with fungal infection should be treated for a minimum of 14 days and treatment should continue for at least 7 days after both neutropenia and clinical symptoms resolve; if there is inadequate response and if 50-mg dose is well tolerated, daily dose may be increased to 70 mg
  • HIV infection - Oropharyngeal candidiasis: (fluconazole-refractory) 50 mg IV daily
  • Oropharyngeal candidiasis: (alternative therapy) 70 mg IV infusion on day 1, followed by 50 mg IV daily thereafter
  • Pulmonary aspergillosis, Chronic (cavitary or necrotizing): (salvage therapy) 70 mg IV infusion on day 1, followed by 50 mg IV daily thereafter

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• safety and effectiveness in children under 3 months of age are not established
  • Aspergillosis, Invasive, salvage therapy: (3 months and older) 70 mg/m(2) IV infusion on day 1 (MAX, 70 mg/dose), then 50 mg/m(2) IV once daily thereafter (MAX, 70 mg/dose); duration of therapy depends upon severity of patient's underlying disease, recovery from immunosuppression, and clinical response; if there is inadequate response and the 50-mg/m(2) dose is well tolerated, daily dose may be increased to 70 mg/m(2) (MAX, 70 mg/dose) (manufacturer dosing)
  • Aspergillosis, Invasive, salvage therapy: 50 mg/m(2) IV daily (guideline dosing)
  • Candidemia: (3 months and older) 70 mg/m(2) IV infusion on day 1 (MAX: 70 mg/dose), then 50 mg/m(2) IV once daily thereafter (MAX: 70 mg/dose); duration of therapy depends upon clinical response and microbiological response; continue for a minimum of 14 days beyond last positive culture; if there is inadequate response and the 50-mg/m(2) dose is well tolerated, daily dose may be increased to 70 mg/m(2) (MAX: 70 mg/dose)
  • Candidiasis of the esophagus: (3 months and older) 70 mg/m(2) IV infusion on day 1 (MAX: 70 mg/dose), then 50 mg/m(2) IV once daily (MAX: 70 mg/dose) for 7 to 14 days after symptom resolution; if there is inadequate response and the 50-mg/m(2) dose is well tolerated, daily dose may be increased to 70 mg/m(2) (MAX: 70 mg/dose)
  • Disseminated candidiasis, Intra-abdominal abscesses, peritonitis, or pleural space infections: 70 mg/m(2) IV infusion on day 1 (MAX: 70 mg/dose), then 50 mg/m(2) IV once daily thereafter (MAX: 70 mg/dose); duration of therapy depends upon clinical response and microbiological response; continue for a minimum of 14 days beyond last positive culture; if there is inadequate response and the 50-mg/m(2) dose is well tolerated, daily dose may be increased to 70 mg/m(2) (MAX: 70 mg/dose)
  • Febrile neutropenia, Empiric antifungal therapy: (3 months and older) 70 mg/m(2) IV infusion on day 1 (MAX: 70 mg/dose), then 50 mg/m(2) IV once daily thereafter (MAX: 70 mg/dose); duration of therapy depends upon clinical response with empirical therapy continued until resolution of neutropenia; patients with fungal infection should be treated for a minimum of 14 days and treatment should continue for at least 7 days after both neutropenia and clinical symptoms resolve; if there is inadequate response and the 50-mg/m(2) dose is well tolerated, daily dose may be increased to 70 mg/m(2) (MAX: 70 mg/dose)

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• (pediatric) coadministration with rifampin, nevirapine, efavirenz, carbamazepine, dexamethasone, or phenytoin: 70 mg/m(2) IV once daily (MAX: 70 mg) is recommended
  • (adults) coadministration with rifampin: 70 mg IV once daily is recommended
  • (adults) coadministration with nevirapine, efavirenz, carbamazepine, dexamethasone, or phenytoin: may consider increase to 70 mg IV once daily
  • (adults) hepatic impairment: moderate impairment (Child-Pugh score 7-9), a 70-mg IV loading dose should be given on day 1 when a loading dose is recommended, followed by 35 mg IV once daily; no data in patients with severe hepatic impairment
  • renal impairment: no dosage adjustment necessary
  • hemodialysis: no dosage adjustment necessary

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Aspergillosis, Invasive, salvage therapy
  • Candidemia
  • Candidiasis of the esophagus
  • Candidiasis of the esophagus - HIV infection
  • Disseminated candidiasis, Intra-abdominal abscesses, peritonitis, or pleural space infections
  • Febrile neutropenia, Empiric antifungal therapy
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Aspergillosis, Invasive, initial therapy
  • Aspergillosis, Invasive - HIV infection
  • Candida endophthalmitis
  • Candidiasis, Cardiovascular system infection
  • Candidiasis, Osteoarticular infection
  • Disseminated candidiasis, Chemotherapy-induced neutropenia; Prophylaxis
  • Disseminated candidiasis, chronic
  • HIV infection - Oropharyngeal candidiasis
  • Invasive fungal infection
  • Invasive fungal infection; Prophylaxis
  • Oropharyngeal candidiasis
  • Pulmonary aspergillosis, Chronic (cavitary or necrotizing)

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: hypersensitivity (eg, anaphylaxis) to caspofungin acetate or to any component of the product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• anaphylaxis has been reported; discontinue use if occurs
  • hepatic abnormalities, including abnormal liver function tests and isolated cases of dysfunction, hepatitis, or hepatic failure, have been reported; monitoring recommended
  • hepatic impairment; dose adjustment may be required
  • histamine-mediated adverse reactions (eg, rash, facial swelling, angioedema, pruritus, sensation of warmth, bronchospasm) have been reported; discontinuation may be necessary
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Caspofungin: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Hypotension (3% to 20%)
  • Dermatologic:Rash (4% to 23%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea (6% to 27%)
  • Hepatic:ALT/SGPT level raised (4% to 18%), AST/SGOT level raised (2% to 17%), Serum alkaline phosphatase raised (9% to 22%)
  • Other:Complication of infusion (20% to 35%), Fever (6% to 30%), Shivering (9% to 23%)
Serious
  • Dermatologic:Erythema multiforme, Stevens-Johnson syndrome
  • Gastrointestinal:Pancreatitis
  • Hepatic:Hepatic necrosis, Liver failure
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis, Sepsis (up to 7%), Septic shock (11% to 14%)
  • Renal:Nephrotoxicity, Renal impairment
  • Respiratory:Pleural effusion (9%), Respiratory distress (up to 8%), Respiratory failure (2% to 20%)
  • Other:Angioedema

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Caspofungin acetate is an antifungal that inhibits beta (1,3)-D-glucan synthesis, an important component of the cell wall of susceptible organisms including Aspergillus and Candida species.

2.title: Metabolism
2.mono:
• spontaneous degradation, hydrolysis and N-acetylation
  • Metabolites: L-747969, dihydroxyhomotyrosine and N-acetyl-dihydroxyhomotyrosine

3.title: Excretion
3.mono:
• Fecal: 35% as metabolites and unchanged drug
  • Renal: 41%, approximately 1.4% unchanged
  • Dialyzable: no

4.title: Elimination Half Life
4.mono:
• Adults: (intravenous, 50 mg/d), 13 +/- 1.9 h
  • Adults: (intravenous, 70 mg/d), 16.5 +/- 7 h
  • Adolescents (aged 12 to 17 years): (intravenous, 50 mg/m(2)/d), 11.2 +/- 1.7 h
  • Children (aged 2 to 11 years): (intravenous, 50 mg/m(2)/d), 8.2 +/- 2.4 h
  • Children (aged 2 to 11 years): (intravenous, 70 mg/m(2)/d), 9.7 +/-2 h

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • do not mix with dextrose-containing solutions
  • reconstitute vial with 10.8 mL of NS, Sterile Water for Injection, or Bacteriostatic Water for Injection to a final concentration of 5 mg/mL for the 50-mg vial and 7 mg/mL for the 70-mg vial (vials contain overfill); reconstituted vials may be stored up to 1 hour at 25 degrees C (77 degrees F) or less; discard unused solution
  • (pediatric patients) reconstituted 50-mg vial (5 mg/mL) should be used for doses less than 50 mg
  • dilute appropriate volume of reconstituted drug in 250 mL or less of NS, 0.45% sodium chloride, 0.225% sodium chloride, or LR; final concentration should not exceed 0.5 mg/mL; diluted solution should be used within 24 hours when stored at 25 degrees C (77 degrees F) or less or within 48 hours when stored in the refrigerator at 2 to 8 degrees C (36 to 46 degrees F)
  • administer as a slow IV infusion over about 1 hour; do not administer as an IV bolus

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• microbiologic clearance of Candida or Aspergillus infection
  • CBC with differential assessment, with normalization of neutrophil count
  • empirical therapy in febrile neutropenia; resolution of fever and signs and symptoms of fungal infection
  • candidiasis; improvement and/or resolution of clinical signs and symptoms of fungal infection
  • invasive aspergillosis; improvement of computed tomography or other radiographic findings
  • liver function tests

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Drug may cause nausea, vomiting, headache, or fever.
  • Instruct patients with history of hepatic impairment to report signs/symptoms of hepatic dysfunction.
